Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2021 Programming Languages Mentoring Workshop at POPL (PLMW@POPL)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: This award seeks to support U.S. student participation in the Programming Languages Mentoring Workshop (PLMW), being organized as part of the ACM SIGACT-SIGPLAN Symposium on Principles of Programming Languages (POPL), the premier conference on programming language theory. The event is in Copenhagen, Denmark in January 2021. This award specifically supports students from underrepresented groups and gives priority to US citizens and permanent residents to attend the mentoring workshop in addition to the POPL conference. The impact of the award relates to broadening participation in computing, providing opportunities for students to receive mentoring from leading researchers, and building the next generation of researchers and knowledgeable practitioners with expertise in programming languages theory.<br/><br/>Students attending the PLMW workshop with support from this grant will hear eminent researchers in the field talk about the latest trends in the field, and get one-on-one mentoring from these speakers and other mentors in research and pursuing their career aspirations. The connections formed at this event will help create lasting connections between researchers and students, thereby shaping emerging innovations in computer programming languages.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Programming Languages Mentoring Workshop (PLMW) brought together graduate students and senior undergraduate students who want to pursue careers in programming language research. The workshop gathered world leaders in programming languages research and teaching from academia and industry to provide (a) technical sessions on cutting­ edge PL research and (b) mentoring sessions on how to prepare for a research career. The workshop engaged students in a process of imagining how they might contribute to programming languages research community. The organizers especially encouraged women and representatives of underserved communities to attend PLMW.

The organizers aimed to attract a diverse audience, targeting new PhD students and upper-level undergraduates. Applicants were asked to provide a short paragraph explaining their interest in PLMW as well as some demographic data. From the applicant pool, the committee scored potential attendees based on a number of criteria suited to identify applicants that would increase diversity, awarding scholarships to as many applicants scoring high as our budget permitted.  A scholarship covered registration (both of the workshop and hosting conference), shared hotel room, and supplemented travel costs.

The award supported the Programming Languages Mentoring Workshop (PLMW) instance associated with the ACM SIGPLAN Symposium on Principles of Programming Languages (POPL) conference, from years 2021 through 2023.  Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the 2021 workshop was a fully virtual event and the 2022 workshop was hybrid, with a significant number of participants opting for online participation on a short notice.  The 2023 workshop took place in person, with a relatively large turnout.
